Award.AwardTitle: Gas Phase Processing for Low Cost Dye Solar Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Energy, Power, and Adaptive Systems (EPAS) Program in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) Program in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Research Objectives and Approaches:
The objective of this research is to use chemical vapor-based atomic and molecular layer deposition methods for the development of highly efficient cost effective organic solar cells with a particular focus on dye solar cells. The approach is multidisciplinary and uses a combined experimental-modeling approach.

Intellectual Merit:
The research addresses the fundamental issues associated with the deposition and characterization of ultra-thin metal oxides and organic dyes on the surface of nanoporous inorganic photoelectrodes along with the characterization and analysis of charge transport at the gas phase synthesized organic-inorganic heterointerfaces. The major research tasks include: 1. Engineering electronic properties of nanostructured heterointerfaces using ultra-thin atomic layer deposited metal oxides, 2. Developing an organic dye loading process using a pulsed molecular layer deposition method, 3. Developing a high throughput DSC process, and 4. Understanding the charge transport and origin of efficiency enhancement in interface engineered DSCs.

Broader impacts:
The proposed research is expected to lead to new methodologies for enhancing electronic quality of photovoltaic heterointerfaces and loading organic light absorbers onto nanostructured inorganic photoelectrodes and open new paradigms in processing and cost-effectiveness of dye solar cells. Topics related to the proposed research will be integrated into the PI's "Fundamentals of Photovoltaics" and "Advanced photovoltaics" courses. This research will involve female students and students from underrepresented groups in the proposed research tasks. A one day long summer camp will be initiated to raise the awareness of Brookings high school students to the science and technology of green energy.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the “Gas Phase Processing for Low Cost Dye Solar Cells” project was to use gas phase deposition techniques to efficiently manufacture and control the properties of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). The most time-consuming steps involved in DSC fabrication are linked with depositing thin films of material on porous electrodes. Therefore, using gas-phase deposition techniques was hypothesized to allow rapid deposition of these films, more uniform surface coverage, and better electron transfer. Over the course of the project, we successfully developed novel gas phase deposition techniques and integrated them into the DSC fabrication process, including a newly patented technique coined Functionalized Carboxylate Deposition (FCD). With FCD, we demonstration an efficient dye loading process lasting 15-20 minutes, about 100 times faster than the conventional wet chemical dye loading process. DSCs produced with FCD and probe dyes (i.e., low molecular weight dyes designated Dye 1 and Dye 2) produced approximately 3.3% efficiency each. These efficiencies are world record efficiencies for these dyes. Following this success, we began work on synthesizing higher efficiency DSC dyes that were compatible with FCD. We successfully synthesized a highly thermally stable N3 analog with FCD compatibility (i.e., N3 is a ruthenium organometallic dye that has produced about 10% efficient DSCs but is not compatible with FCD) and evaporated the N3 analog without significant thermal degradation in a custom FCD instrument. We are currently characterizing the N3 analog and will shortly fabricate DSCs based on FCD processing with this dye. Additionally, we pioneered a spray deposition technique to deposit platinum nanoparticles as a counterelectrode that uses about 10 times less material than the conventional sputter deposition method. The Pt nanoparticle layer is about 90% transparent and its catalytic activity is comparable to that of the conventional sputter deposited Pt counter electrodes. We demonstrated 6.17% conversion efficiency for DSCs with the transparent counter electrode and N719 dye.

An additional objective was to build on previous work to model energy transport in DSCs. The most significant achievement related to this objective was the development and experimental validation of a new charge transport model for DSCs based on trap-assisted interfacial charge transfer. The model explains a number of difficult to model phenomena, including dark and illuminated current-voltage and quantum efficiency characteristics of DSCs.

The experimental portion of the project will impact the fields of Chemistry and Engineering specifically in the creation of hybrid materials and the fabrication of dye-sensitized solar cells. The deposition technique developed, FCD, is a new method to create hybrid materials in minutes, versus the hours necessary for wet chemical processes. Therefore, this technique has the possibility of impacting multiple fields outside the main goals of this project. For example, hybrid materials are used extensively in separation science and FCD may allow rapid creation of these materials. At minimum, similar hybrid materials can be produced by FCD in a fraction of the time as wet chemical processes. The modeling portion of this work will impact the field of solar cell technology by allowing predictive information to guide researchers to more efficient solar cell technology through careful selection of materials and processing as indicated by the model. Overall, this project has produced many significant results and may propagate into the scientific knowledge base for long after the project has finished.

To date, the results of the research were published in five peer-reviewed publications, four more papers are currently in preparation or submitted to journals, and 11 conference papers were presented during the project, t...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main objective of the "Gas Phase Processing for Low Cost Dye Solar Cells" project was to use gas phase deposition techniques to efficiently manufacture and control the properties of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). The most time-consuming steps involved in DSC fabrication are linked with depositing thin films of material on porous electrodes. Therefore, using gas-phase deposition techniques was hypothesized to allow rapid deposition of these films, more uniform surface coverage, and better electron transfer. Over the course of the project, we successfully developed novel gas phase deposition techniques and integrated them into the DSC fabrication process, including a newly patented technique coined Functionalized Carboxylate Deposition (FCD). With FCD, we demonstration an efficient dye loading process lasting 15-20 minutes, about 100 times faster than the conventional wet chemical dye loading process. DSCs produced with FCD and probe dyes (i.e., low molecular weight dyes designated Dye 1 and Dye 2) produced approximately 3.3% efficiency each. These efficiencies are world record efficiencies for these dyes. Following this success, we began work on synthesizing higher efficiency DSC dyes that were compatible with FCD. We successfully synthesized a highly thermally stable N3 analog with FCD compatibility (i.e., N3 is a ruthenium organometallic dye that has produced about 10% efficient DSCs but is not compatible with FCD) and evaporated the N3 analog without significant thermal degradation in a custom FCD instrument. We are currently characterizing the N3 analog and will shortly fabricate DSCs based on FCD processing with this dye. Additionally, we pioneered a spray deposition technique to deposit platinum nanoparticles as a counterelectrode that uses about 10 times less material than the conventional sputter deposition method. The Pt nanoparticle layer is about 90% transparent and its catalytic activity is comparable to that of the conventional sputter deposited Pt counter electrodes. We demonstrated 6.17% conversion efficiency for DSCs with the transparent counter electrode and N719 dye. An additional objective was to build on previous work to model energy transport in DSCs. The most significant achievement related to this objective was the development and experimental validation of a new charge transport model for DSCs based on trap-assisted interfacial charge transfer. The model explains a number of difficult to model phenomena, including dark and illuminated current-voltage and quantum efficiency characteristics of DSCs. The experimental portion of the project will impact the fields of Chemistry and Engineering specifically in the creation of hybrid materials and the fabrication of dye-sensitized solar cells. The deposition technique developed, FCD, is a new method to create hybrid materials in minutes, versus the hours necessary for wet chemical processes. Therefore, this technique has the possibility of impacting multiple fields outside the main goals of this project. For example, hybrid materials are used extensively in separation science and FCD may allow rapid creation of these materials. At minimum, similar hybrid materials can be produced by FCD in a fraction of the time as wet chemical processes. The modeling portion of this work will impact the field of solar cell technology by allowing predictive information to guide researchers to more efficient solar cell technology through careful selection of materials and processing as indicated by the model. Overall, this project has produced many significant results and may propagate into the scientific knowledge base for long after the project has finished. To date, the results of the research were published in five peer-reviewed publications, four more papers are currently in preparation or submitted to journals, and 11 conference papers were presented during the project, to include Material Research Symposia, a Photovoltaic Specialist Conference, a National ACS m...
